text: An idyllic American factory. There's a huge, long lawn in front. A Reynolds Extract sign in brick with flowers/landscaping around it, sits near the entrance. We see from the number of cars in the parking lot that it's company of about 50 - 75 employees.

We are in a manufacturing area of an assembly-line production. It's a big room full of intricate machines, h vats of different colored extract and other food flavorin products, conveyor belts, bottling machines, etc. It has high ceiling with offices on the second floor that have b windows overlooking this manufacturing area. We PAN up to the main office.
JOEL REYNOLDS, head of the company, mid-thirties, is on t phone with his friend DEAN. DEAN (v.o.) You should come by tonight. Half price well drinks while the game's going.
You always give me free drinks though. DEAN (v.o.) Oh yeah. Well come by anyway.
Yeah?... Might as well. No action going on at my house, that's for sure. DEAN (v.o.) Really? The wife out of town?
No... I just haven't been laid in a month. 2. DEAN (v.o.) You guys having problems or something?

No. This is pretty much normal these days... As CREDITS continue, camera PULLS OUT, back down to the manufacturing area, past a big vat of orange extract, dow through various stages of assembly line production, then follows several bottles of orange extract moving past HECTOR, a Mexican immigrant employee in his thirties. The camera stops on him. Talking to Hector is STEP, a short, beady-eyed Charles-Manson-looking guy with a beard and mustache. Step is in his forties. He makes everything he says sound as macho and important as possible.
You get this job through Manpower?
Yeah.
I started here with Manpower too. Started out on the line just like you.

Only I did better... 40 crates a day.  Beat. Hector is not quite sure what he's talking about. STEP continues telling his tale in such a way that the on polite reaction would be one of total amazement.

I'm the best sorter in here. That's why they made me full time with benefits. I'll probably be floor manager this year. A FEW FEET AWAY we see RORY, a stocky indie-rock geek, wi too many tatoos, hair shaved on the side with a ponytail, lots of bad piercings, wearing baggy shorts with lots of pockets and some kind of gothy T-shirt -- a look that oug to be out of style by now. 3. Rory is putting stickers on boxes with a sticker gun. He flips the sticker gun around unnecessarily between each application, adding a few unnecessary moves/motions, slap each box when he's done, generally making the activity lo like more of a skill than it actually is. He approaches S and Hector, pulling out some fliers from his many pockets

(hands them each a flier) My band's playing this Friday, come check us out. Hector looks down at the flier. It's xeroxed with fifties clip-art, cut out letters and the name of the band, "God' Cock". Hector just looks at it confused, not knowing much English, not sure what he's supposed to be doing with the flier. AT THE END OF THE LINE, where boxes are loaded onto palle sits MARY, 58 years old, wearing a 15-year-old pair of ac wash jeans, and an oversized tweety-bird T-shirt, fanny p and dayglow yellow triangle-shaped earrings. She's pear- shaped with short hair. She's bitter and bossy, always shaking her head at everyone. She sits on a stool with a clipboard, looks over her glasses at Hector, shaking her head. She talks to Gabriella, a Hispanic woman in her forties.
You see that... That new guy. He's holding us up. It's not my job to tell them to hold the line either.
And then Joel's gonna come yell at us, cuz he's not doing his job.
(folds her arms, fed up) I'm just gonna sit here.
You're not gonna shut it off?
I'm not gonna hold the line. If they're not gonna do their job, why should I do mine. Mary sits there, arms folded, lips pursed, refusing to pa the conveyor belt. 4.
Joel is still on the phone with Dean.
If I don't get home before about 8:00, she puts on the sweatpants and once the sweatpants are on, it's over -- I get nothing. (notices something down
Shit. I'm gonna have to call you back. Joel hangs up and runs downstairs.
Boxes start to accumulate and fall off the end of the lin Step sees this, runs to shut off the line, yelling at Mar
What are you doing?!
What are YOU doing?! (pointing at Hector) What is he doing? A YELLING/BICKERING MATCH breaks out between Mary, Step, and Gabriella. Joel runs over, shuts off the conveyor bel
All right. Now, what's the problem? They all erupt in more BICKERING AND FINGER POINTING.
Okay! Okay, everyone settle down. Now Mary. Hector here is new okay? It's gonna take him a couple of days, maybe his English isn't so good. You gotta be patient.
That's what I was tryin' to say.
And Step, if you wanna be Floor Manager, this is the kind of thing you're going to have to deal with. 5.
Exactly.

Okay, now Step, Rory, Hector, let's get this cleaned up, and get rolling again. We can't afford to fall behind today. Joel walks away. People resume their posts. Mary starts right back up with Gabriella.
You see that? We always get the blame.

Joel sits in his swivel chair, looking down at the produc floor, shaking his head. BRIAN, Joel's second in command, walks in. He's a little older than Joel, neatly trimmed beard, aviator glasses, and a bit of a gut. He wears a Reynold's Extract golf shirt and Khaki pants. He walks ov to the window, joins Joel, looking down at the employees.
Jesus... They're like a bunch of  goddamned children.
Tell me about it. Sorry I missed the drama; I was showing boy-genius down there how to back up a forklift. ANGLE ON Rory, driving the forklift, handing out a flier he passes someone.
That's his whole career, driving that damn forklift. You'd think he'd wanna learn how.
Well, I guess he's got that band  he's in too...
(disgust at the word
"Band", ugh...
I'll bet dollars to donuts he sucks at that too. Then you got ah... (tries to remember her name but can't) Dinkus down there...
Who, Mary?

No, the other one -- what's-her- face -- she asked me -- or rather "axed" me -- for more personal days. Just like that. I told her maybe if she figures out how to fill out the time sheets correctly I'll give her more personal days... (Off Joel's look) Don't worry, she will never fill out her time sheets correctly. Joel looks down at the production floor. Joel's POV:  ANGLE ON: Mary and Step bickering. Step walks off. Mary a Gabrielle shaking their heads and yapping like a couple o old hens.
Look at 'em... I am so sick of baby sitting these assholes. (looks at his watch) I better get going... Joel leaves in a hurry, mumbling something about  "sweatpants."
Joel drives home, in a hurry, checking his dashboard cloc It's an upscale neighborhood of McMansions in a town like Lincoln Nebraska. He turns a corner, slows down suddenly when he sees something.
NATHAN, a middle-aged, overweight, annoying guy is going to the street to get his mail.

(to himself, praying) Please go back inside... Please just turn around.. .Come on...don't notice me... 7. It's too late. Nathan turns, sees Joel's car and waves, t crosses the street to Joel's driveway and waits to talk t him.
Shit! Joel pulls into his driveway as Nathan flags him down. Jo begrudgingly rolls down the passenger side window so Nath can talk to him.
Hi there Joel! Glad I caught ya... Nathan settles in like he's going to be there a while, leaning with his arms folded, hanging inside the car, trapping Joel.
How've ya been? I left you a message last week. I don't know if you got it or not.
Yeah, actually Nathan, I'm kind of in a hurry here.
Oh yeah? You been busy?
Yeah, in fact... (checks his watch) I should go right now actually. I gotta call the office before they leave.
Well, real quick while I got ya here -- what're you guys doing November 17th?
Ah, I don't ah... (realizes his should fake
Actually we're going to be out of town that weekend.
Oh yeah? Where you going? 8.
Ah...
Oh, wait a minute -- I'm sorry, I meant the 7th. Yeah, November 7th. You'll be in town then right?
Ah...Yeah.

Great. There's this dinner Leslie and I are going to. It's an annual thing -- we do it every year with the Rotary Club -- it's for charity. It's just a whole lot of fun, and we wanted to invite you and Suzie to be our guests at our table. It's--
I'm sorry, I ah... I just don't think that's something we're gonna want to do.
Really? Why not? It's a lot of fun.
Oh, I don't know. Suzie doesn't really like going to stuff like
Why not?
Well, we wouldn't know anybody there. She get's kind of uncomfortable.
Oh no -- It's not like that. She won't be uncomfortable. I guarantee it. No, it's not like that at all. It's not formal or anything. Trust me. It's just a real loose bunch. 9.
I just don't...

I tell you what. Why don't we do this -- I'll go ahead and get tickets, since they're gonna sell out fast. You talk to Suzie. See what she says. Like I say, she won't be uncomfortable at all. Maybe I'll have Leslie give her a call -- you know how it is when the wives talk, heh heh-- Joel is about to snap.
Um, why don't we talk about this later. (looks at his watch) I gotta make this call before they leave. Joel pulls away, forcing Nathan to raise off the window s
Sorry... I just gotta make this call!
Joel pulls the car in, steps out and is shocked to see Na right there in his garage.

Sorry, I almost forgot -- the tickets are forty dollars a plate. I know that's a little steep, but the food is fantastic and it's for a good cause. So that'd be eighty dollars total. There's no tax or anything.

Ah, look Nathan, I really gotta get inside and make this call. Let's talk about this another time. Joel has his finger on the button to shut the garage door waiting for Nathan to get out. Nathan stops, just inside. 10.
Oh, and if you need us to look out for the house or anything when you go out of town -- Joel's finger still on the garage door button.
Well, just let us know. Where you guys going anyway?
Ah, just sort of a vacation. Look, I gotta run. Joel hits the button and the door starts going down.
Alright then. We'll see ya. Nathan finally steps out of the garage. Joel breaths a hu sigh of relief. Then,
As it gets halfway down, we see Nathan's legs, heading ba towards the door. Nathan leans down into frame as the doo goes down.
Oh, Joel one more thing-- Joel lets the door shut on him, and bolts into the house.
Joel walks into the living room just as his wife, SUZIE, enters from the bedroom pulling on her SWEATPANTS. A look disappointment on Joel's face. Suzie is a decent looking woman, about Joel's age.
Man, that Nathan won't shut up.
Yeah, what an asshole. I don't even go into the front yard anymore. That wife of his is even worse. 11. Suzie plops down on the couch looking tired and pissed of Joel sits down next to her.

We gotta get a new pool cleaner.I don't think that asshole checked the chlorine levels again like I asked him too... Joel puts his arm around her, caresses her shoulder. She doesn't seem to notice as he starts getting fresh.

.and every time he is here, he goes on and on about some problem with the goddamn filter, and I have no idea what he's talking about... Delayed reaction -- she notices Joel is getting frisky. H gets closer, starts kissing her neck.
Ah,...Joel?
What?
I'm sorry. It's just... I'm a little tired, and, I don't know, it's the middle of the week...
It's not the middle of the week. It's Monday. Why can't--
Monday? (Freezes, suddenly
Oh shit!
What?!
Idol! Suzie jumps up with newfound energy, runs for the remote turns on the TV. Joel just sits there. 12. Suzie plops down in a Barcalounger.
Sorry honey. Maybe this weekend. Joel leaves the room.
[Quick scene of Joel trying to masturbate (off screen of course), but he's too distracted by the sounds of a bad o of-tune Idol audition blaring through the wall.]
Establishing shot. A sports bar that's part of a Holiday Inn.
Joel sits at the bar. DEAN, the owner of the bar, late forties, and an old friend of Joel's, sits behind the bar a stool.
I gotta get a house with a bathroom that's doesn't share a wall with the TV.
Why don't you do that in another bathroom. You've got three of 'em.
It would look suspicious. We never use those other bathrooms... Maybe if I had some insulation put in...

Insulation?... All I know is, you shouldn't move man; you've got a nice house. I mean you've got the American dream really -- you own your own company. I can't believe you used to bar back for me here, and now you've got all that.
But what do I have really? It's a big pain in the ass.

I'm always working; can't stop or the whole place will fall apart. And what good does it do me anyway? I don't get laid. That stock guy with the shitty band that works for me probably gets laid more than I do.
(trying to help) Yeah, but he probably lives in a crappy apartment.
Hell, I'd move into a crappy apartment if the bathroom wasn't right next to the TV.

CINDY, a girl in her early twenties, is at the counter looking at a new Gibson hollow-body electric guitar -- on the really nice ones. The price tag says $3,950. She's beautiful and sexy and all that, but there's something vulnerable and sweet about her as well. Two SALESMEN, typical music store employees -- long-haire goateed, nerdy cocky guitar-hacks are giving her way too attention. It's clear that they don't usually have women this hot in their store. They practically stumble over ea other trying to help her.
Yeah, it's expensive but it's sweet... Are you familiar with the Gibson humbucking pickups?
No, sorry. I don't play. It's for my Dad actually -- for his fiftieth birthday. My sisters and I are all pitching in.

Ah, that's nice... Your Dad would love these humbuckings. They really kick ass. An annoyed MALE CUSTOMER has been waiting behind Cindy, trying to get some help, but he might as well be invisibl He tries to address Salesman #2, off to the side. 14.
Excuse me... I just have a quick question... Salesman #2 is oblivious, never takes his eyes off Cindy.
So, what kind of music did he play? Both Salesmen's eyes are glued to Cindy as Male Customer finally gets sick of waiting and storms off into the keyb room.
I think he played like, jazz or something. I'm not sure.
Well this is an excellent jazz guitar. It's what Pat Metheny plays.
Is your Dad into Metheny at all?
Oh, I don't know who that is. Sorry.
He's like, a totally kickass fusion guitarist. Are you into fusion?
I don't really know much about it...
I play fusion guitar so... Just curious.
Um, do they come in any other colors?
You mean different finishes? There's a sunburst finish we might have in stock. 15.
Yeah, do you wanna see it? I'll go get it.
Or I could go. Whatever.
Are you sure?

Oh totally./ No prob!/ I'll show you the case it comes with too. The salesmen practically trip over each other, going into back to find the other guitar. Cindy stands there alone for a beat. She looks around. Th casually picks up the four-thousand dollar guitar and wal out the front door with it.
Cindy walks a few yards over to her car, a ' 92 Tercel, p the guitar in the trunk, gets in and takes off.

The two Salesmen return -- one carrying the sunburst-fini guitar and the other with the hard-shell case. They look around, notice she's gone. They stand there for a beat, disappointed, before they realize what just happened.
Oh shit!...
They run out the front door, but Cindy is long gone.
Joel is at his desk. Brian comes in, excited.
You're not gonna believe this. Remember the guy from General Mills that called a while back? Talking like he wanted to buy us out? 16.
I thought you said he wasn't serious; he was just sniffing around.
Yeah, well he's serious now. He just made an offer -- I mean a real offer this time.
You're kidding.
No. It must be part of some bigger strategic move, because it's over market value I think.
Wow... Joel lets it sink in. He walks over to the window, lookin down on the production floor.
I could unload all this... I could probably retire...

I mean, yeah, there's a lot of details to work out, but this could be great. They'll be calling back next week, what should I tell them? Joel looks down, sees Mary sitting with her arms folded, shaking her head.
Tell 'em hell yes.
Mary sits with her arms folded, refusing to hold the line

I already warned him. This is the last time. I'm just gonna sit here. In SLOW MOTION, we see: 17. - The first box falls off the end of the assembly line, bottles shatter. - Rory, carrying some boxes slips on the broken bottles o goopey extract, falls and slides into an aisle. - A forklift stops suddenly to avoid hitting Rory, causin huge stack of pallets to fall off. - Quick shot of Mary shaking her head in slow-motion. - Just as Step rounds a corner to see what's going on, th pallets land on a bunch of pipes and high-pressure valves which burst open sending a piece of shrapnel flying acros the room heading straight for - STEP'S CROTCH. The shrapnel heads straight for his genitalia, as we

Step is on a stretcher being loaded into a MEDIVAC helico by a couple of EMS guys. Step moans in pain as Joel tries comfort him. A small crowd of employees watch. ANGLE ON Mary in the crowd, shaking her head.
I knew it. That's what happens when you don't pay attention.
Joel sits at the bar, on a cell phone. Dean sits behind t bar on a stool.
(to the person on the
Uh-huh... Alright. Let me know if you hear anything else. He hangs up, talks to Dean.
Well, he's definitely lost one of 'em. They think they might be able to re-attach the other one, but they're not sure. 18.
(shaking his head) Wow...
Yeah... I'm not sure how it happened, but we have a great safety record and we comply with all the safety codes so... it was just a freak accident. There'll be an investigation of some kind I'm sure.
Well, you have insurance for that kind of thing, right?
Oh yeah. Of course. In fact, he'll probably get a huge settlement.
Yeah. I would think so. I mean, it's your balls... Beat, as they contemplate the profundity of it.
Boy it really makes you stop and think about how fragile we are -- especially our balls. They're just hanging there in a little sack between our legs. At any moment they could be cut off forever.
Yeah. And your balls are really important man. Your balls are everything. What kind of life would you have with no testicles? Can you imagine that shit?
Yeah... Beat.
You know Dean, my life wouldn't be much different than it is now actually.
Except for once every three months when I have sex with my wife. In fact, I might even be better off...
Wait. Three months? I thought you said it was once a month.
I did? I must've been lying. I don't know... Maybe things'll get better when I sell the company. I'll be around more...
Well, I hope so. That would suck... I get laid all the time. (off Joel's reaction) Sorry.
Ah, it's all right...
Actually, it sucks.
Yeah, sexual frustration is bad news... You know what you oughtta do?
What?
Get some Xanax.
Xanax? Isn't that for anxiety?

Yeah it is, but I find it's good for just about any phsychological problem. I mean, basically it just makes you feel good, so it sort of works for anything. I even take it when I have a cold. It's probably great for sexual frustration. Want me to get you some?
You know what else is good? Codeine cough syrup.
For what?
It's just good. Joel looks at Dean for a beat.
Are you on something now?
No... Well, I guess I took some Vicodin this morning. But that was just 'cause I was hung-over.
Establishing shot, a pawn shop in a strip mall. Cindy's c parked out in front.
Cindy is at the counter, the Gibson guitar we saw earlier in front of her. A PAWN SHOP GUY is counting out money. H pauses, looks around, then speaks sympathetically to her.
Um, you know, I'm really not supposed to say this... but since this belonged to your father, and since he passed away and all...
You could probably get a better deal at a music store.
Oh, that's okay. Thanks. But I just kind of wanna get it over with, you know? It's kind of hard for me.
I understand. He looks around to see if his boss is watching, then coun off a FEW MORE TWENTIES, feeling sorry for her. 21. PAWN SHOP GUY (cont'd) Here.

Cindy puts the money in her wallet, along with a driver's license. CLOSE ON THE WALLET. Cindy shuffles through three or four different driver's licenses. On one, her name says MISTY PATTERSON. It's a Kansas license. She takes another one out from Colorado, with the name CINDY METZLER on it and puts that in front, then puts the wallet away. A newspaper sits on the front seat. Something grabs her attention.
We see an article about Step's accident. There's a pictur of Step being taken away on the stretcher. Cindy starts reading the article, with growing interest.

She scans the article, zeroing in on certain words, ".. .potentially big settlement..." "...no testicles..." "several million dollars" then back to "no testicles" the quickly back and forth several times -- "million dollars" testicles" "million dollars" "no testicles" ON CINDY'S FACE - A look of determination. She looks one more time at the name under the picture -- Don "Step" Wilkenson, then zeroes in on the words "Reynold's Extract She starts the car and speeds away.
Joel sits with Brian. Brian has a clipboard, going over t day's business.
So obviously Step's not coming back anytime soon. I had to hire a couple temps. Is that okay?
Yeah, sure. How is Step?  22.

Better. They say he's going home in a couple of days. Speaking of which, the guys at General Mills heard about this whole Step thing. They're worried. If Step decides to sue us -- beyond the insurance settlement -- it could be a serious liability. They don't want to make an offer until this thing has settled.
Really? They think it's that big  of a liability?

Well yeah. Don't you? I mean, think about it. Imagine if you asked a bunch of jurors how much you'd have to pay 'em to cut their balls off? I mean, I wouldn't let someone cut my balls off for a billion dollars. Seriously -- unless there were some kind of really expensive operation that could give you artificial balls or something. Would you?
No, I guess not.
Anyway, I wouldn't worry. He says he's not going to sue us. Says he
"don't want somethin' fer nothin "' and "What's right is right." If we can just get him to sign something to that effect we should be fine.
Boy, Step sure is being mellow  about all this.
Yeah, well I think when you lose your balls it mellows you out. You don't get as pissed off and aggressive about things. I know it's true for horses, and bulls. 23.
Boy, it sure does make you think..
Oh, by the way, guess who asked for  a raise today?
Who?
to someone downstairs) Dinkus. Can you believe that?
Brian, you call everyone here "Dinkus." I don't know who you're talking about.
You know, Forklift-Dinkus?
Oh... I thought you call him "boy-  genius."
Yeah, well boy-genius asked for a raise. I said, "are you kidding? You nearly got someone killed last week," and then he blamed it on Dinkus over there.
You know Brian, you really ought to  learn the employees' names.
Well, I was thinking about that, but hey, if this deal goes through next week, I won't have to. It's not like I'm gonna be inviting Dinkus and Boy-Genius over for dinner.
Joel stands on one side of his office looking down throug long window overlooking the manufacturing area. Dean come in, walks over to the window, looks down at the productio floor with Joel. 24.
Hey man. What's goin' o-- Whoa! DEAN'S POV: It's CINDY, now working down on the floor, on the assembley line.
Damn! Who's she? Is she new?
Yeah. She's a temp.
She's a tramp?
No a temp. Quit staring.
Damn, she's hot! Way to go.
Hey, I didn't hire her. She came here through Manpower, like everybody else. They just sent her over.
Manpower, huh? Maybe I should give them a call. You don't usually have girls anywhere near that hot working here. What's the deal?
Yeah, I know. I guess it makes sense though if you think about it. Hot girls need a job just as much as anyone else.
(thinks for a second) Do they really?... Huh... You just don't see 'em here. Usually your temps look like winos. And they're guys.
You wanna hear something really weird?
What? 25.
She came on to me.
No way! Really?
Yeah. I mean, I'm pretty sure. I could be wrong, but...
Hey, I'm sure she did. Are you kidding? You could have any girl down there.
I don't know about that.
I'm serious. Dude, you're the big shot here. You're the king of... What do you call that shit you make here again?
Extract. And spray-dried flavoring, and we're branching out
Yeah, you're the Extract King man. You could have any girl here. I mean, I wouldn't want most of 'em, but her... Way to go Joel. Dean looks down at manufacturing area, taking it all in.
So how did she come on to you?
Well, first she started asking me about what happened to Step and all that stuff -- you know, just sort of making conversation?
Yeah.
But it really seemed like she was flirting with me, you know?
Then, she just sort of asked me out... I think.
Really? How?
Well, you see that guy down there by the fork lift? ANGLE ON Rory, the indi-rock guy with tattoos, etc.
His band is playing somewhere, at some party this weekend, and she asked me if I wanted to go with her.
Wow. So, you gonna do anything about it?
What? No. No way. I couldn't live with myself if I cheated on Suzie... It'd be nice if I got laid at home once in a while though...
(still staring at her) Man, she is fine. You mind if I hit that then? Beat.
Yeah, I do sort of... We see a COMMOTION down on the floor. Mary runs out of th Women's locker room SCREAMING AND YELLING.
Mary runs over to where Hector is working, hysterical.

My purse is stolen! It's gone! (pointing at Hector) He did it! He stole my purse! 27. Brian runs over and stands between them, trying to calm M down, but she keeps ranting. Hector looks confused and worried.
Now hold on--
I won't hold on! I'll call the cops!
(confused, frightened) What? I don'... No comprende...
Espera un momento Hector. Tu sabes donde esta su... uh, purse? ANGLE ON CINDY, watching the whole thing-- completely unfazed.Joel rushes in.
Now wait a second. Calm down Mary. How do you know it was stolen?
It's gone! That's how.
Well, what did it look like.
It was black with a fur, leopard style border... As Mary describes the purse, we

Cindy sits in her parked car, going through the purse Mar just described. She takes some cash, puts it in her pocke then finds what she's looking for -- the address book. ANGLE ON ADDRESS BOOK. Cindy turns to the Ws and finds Step Wilkenson. She notes his address. She starts the car and takes off. 28.

location: STREET IN FRONT OF STEP'S HOUSE

text: Cindy sits and waits, listening to the radio. It's a very blue-collar neighborhood. She's about three houses away f Step's house, keeping an eye on it. After a beat, Step limps out of the house, walks over to pickup truck, painfully gets in, and leaves. Cindy starts the car and follows from a distance.

Step wheels his shopping cart into one of the checkout li He uses the cart as a crutch to help him walk. Cindy gets line behind him. She only has one item, a bottle of Reynold's Orange Extract. Step notices her.
You can go ahead of me if that's all you have.
Thank you so much. (holds up extract bottle) I can't believe I'm buying this stuff -- I work at the factory.
Really? I work there too. Or, ah, I used to.
Really? You're kidding! I just started there. What's your name?
I go by Step. Yeah, I'm the fastest sorter there... As Cindy and Step get to know each other we
Joel enters the living room. He first sees the sweatpants then sees Suzie is sound asleep on the couch. He sighs, t turns and leaves. 29.
Joel sits at the bar talking to Dean. Joel is drinking so kind of hard liquor, getting a buzz.
I'm sick of it Dean. I'm sick of being turned down in my own house by my own wife. We're turning into one of those brother-sister couples.
Huh...Now that you mention it, you guys kind of look alike too.
No we don't!
Okay.
(takes a drink) Maybe things will be better after I sell the company... Or maybe it's just going to mean more time to sit around and contemplate not getting laid. Dean nods sympathetically.
What about that girl at work? She still into you?

Yeah... she was really coming on to me. She gave me her phone number and everything. Told me to call her if I wanted to go to that party. Can you believe that? And there's nothing I can do about it, but just be sexually frustrated.
I've got some Xanax if you want it. Like I say, that always works for me. 30.
No thanks...
Well maybe you should call that girl.
No, I can't. I can't cheat on Suzie. I just gotta power through it until I'm so old that I can't get it up anymore.
What about if Suzie cheated on you?
Hmm... I hadn't even thought of that...
I wish she would.
You wish she would cheat on you? Wouldn't that bother you? Joel thinks about it.
No. I don't think it would actually. (occuring to him) I guess that's weird huh?
Yeah, it's a little weird. Sort of.
But see, then I could do something about all this sexual frustration, without feeling guilty about it.
Do you think she would cheat on you?
Nah...
You sure? 31.
Well, I don't know. Hmm... Maybe if she were really tempted she would. Like if some really studly guy came on to her.
So you're saying she would probably cheat on you if she was put in temptation's way?
Yeah, maybe.
You know what you oughtta do?
I don't wanna do any drugs Dean.
No, no. Check this out -- If you really wish your wife would cheat on you, it's not that hard to make it happen.
How?
Hire a gigolo to have an affair with your wife.
